GPT is a power tool. Judgment is still the main Product manager job.

I‚Äôve been reviewing a lot of PRDs recently, and I‚Äôve noticed something worrying.
Some product managers are now using GPT to drive their thinking instead of support it.
The result? Documents that check every box of a PRD template‚Ä¶ but are full of confusion. To a junior PM, it looks polished. To an experienced eye, it‚Äôs mostly noise.

To be clear: GPT is extremely powerful. We use it daily. But like any power tool, the outcome depends on the craftsperson. When GPT leads, it can produce confident structure without correct substance‚Äîand that‚Äôs hard to detect if you‚Äôre early in your career.

Where GPT shines
-Evidence gathering: pull prior art, benchmarks, and user quotes.
-Synthesis: compress interviews/notes into themes and edge cases.
-Exploration: generate alternative framings, risks, and test scenarios.
-Communication: first drafts of release notes, FAQs, checklists.

What you should not outsource
-Problem definition: who is the user, what‚Äôs the job, what hurts now.
-Context + constraints: compliance, data realities, org priorities.
-Prioritization and trade-offs: what we will not build and why.
Decision ownership: success metrics, guardrails, and accountability.

A simple review test I use
Few sentence problem (no AI): if you can‚Äôt state it cleanly, you‚Äôre not ready to draft.
Evidence trace: every user scenario ties to a source or observation.
Decisions > templates: I look for rationale, not headings.

GPT should amplify your clarity, not simulate it. If the first time you feel ‚Äúclear‚Äù is after the AI draft, that‚Äôs a warning sign.
To young professionals (PMs and beyond): master the thinking, then use GPT to accelerate it. Tools compound good judgment; they can‚Äôt replace it.
‚Äî Curious to hear how other product teams are seeing the impact of AI in their world.

postContent:
üß† Are LLMs just pattern matchers? A recent debate has reignited this foundational AI question.

It started with an Apple research paper that argued today‚Äôs AI systems‚Äîincluding large language models‚Äîare not truly ‚Äúreasoning.‚Äù They‚Äôre just doing statistical pattern matching at scale. No abstraction, no understanding, no causality‚Äîjust very good autocomplete.

In response, Ilya Sutskever (co-founder of OpenAI) delivered a lecture where he flipped the script:

> ‚ÄúOur brains are also just giant pattern matchers.‚Äù



His point? Intelligence doesn‚Äôt require symbolic logic or explicit reasoning steps. The human brain learns from patterns too‚Äîassociations, reinforcement, feedback. And LLMs are perhaps walking the same evolutionary path, just digitally.

But here‚Äôs a missing piece that neither side emphasizes enough:
The substrate matters.

üß† Human brains are massively parallel, analog, and energy efficient. Neurons can fire with infinite gradations, and billions of them operate simultaneously. Pattern matching in the brain can involve emotional nuance, parallel thoughts, and contextual awareness‚Äîall happening together.

üíª AI systems, on the other hand, run on silicon chips. Even with GPUs and TPUs, they‚Äôre fundamentally linear, digital, and binary. A transistor can be ON or OFF. Parallelism is simulated, and multitasking is expensive. When an LLM generates a sentence, it's not juggling multiple perspectives in the way a human does‚Äîit‚Äôs walking one path at a time, very fast.

So yes, maybe both brains and LLMs are pattern matchers.
But only one of them is doing it in wetware, with organic nuance and infinite resolution. The other is stuck in silicon.

And perhaps, that difference still matters more than we think.

postContent:
API vs MCP vs A2A ‚Äî What‚Äôs the Difference, and Why It Matters
There‚Äôs a lot of buzz around new AI frameworks like MCP and A2A, and many people are asking ‚Äî how are these different from traditional APIs?

Let‚Äôs break it down with simple examples:
1. APIs (Application Programming Interfaces)
 APIs are how different apps talk to each other ‚Äî especially when they‚Äôre owned by different teams or companies.
Example:
 Your app wants to check the credit score of a user. You hit an external credit bureau‚Äôs API, which returns a score.
 The bureau decides what data to expose, how often, and in what format.
APIs are great for external world integration ‚Äî clean, secure, versioned. But they require agreement, documentation, and often strict access control.
 You don‚Äôt see what‚Äôs behind the curtain ‚Äî you just use what‚Äôs offered.

2. MCP (Model-Context Protocol)
 Introduced by Anthropic, MCP allows LLMs to interact with external tools and data via a standardized interface. It‚Äôs still a one-model world, but you feed it structured access to plugins and databases.
Example:
 An LLM helping a customer support agent might use MCP to look up order history, check return status, or send a refund ‚Äî all through tools connected via this common protocol.
MCP is about making a single AI model smarter by giving it controlled access to context and tools.
 It reduces the need to hard-code every integration.

3. A2A (Agent-to-Agent Framework)
 This is where things shift from integration to collaboration. With A2A, different AI agents can talk to each other, negotiate, and complete tasks together ‚Äî even across systems ‚Äî without needing formal APIs exposed.
Example:
A lightweight agent on your app checks user inputs
It passes the data to a document-verifying agent
That agent flags inconsistencies and triggers a risk-check agent
All this happens internally, without each system exposing APIs or standardizing requests
It‚Äôs like RPA ‚Äî but no humans in the loop, and far more intelligence.

The Big Shift
API: You tell me what you expose, and I‚Äôll write code to use it.
MCP: I‚Äôm one smart AI, and I know how to use tools if you give me handles.
A2A: I‚Äôm part of a team of smart agents. We‚Äôll talk, figure it out, and get the job done ‚Äî no need to call IT to expose a new API.

This opens up exciting new possibilities:
-Teams don‚Äôt have to standardize every backend operation into an API
-On-device agents can handle more on the edge
-Internal workflows become more autonomous and scalable

The AI architecture of the future won‚Äôt be a single genius model ‚Äî it‚Äôll be a team of capable agents talking to each other.
Let me know what you think ‚Äî or if you‚Äôve started playing with these ideas. Would love to hear more use cases.

postContent:
Google just launched something interesting in the AI space called A2A (Agent-to-Agent). It‚Äôs a framework where different AI agents can talk to each other, work together, and check each other‚Äôs work.
Instead of one big model doing everything, A2A lets multiple smaller agents handle different tasks ‚Äî like writing code, reviewing it, and deciding what to do next. Kind of like how real teams operate.
What‚Äôs exciting here is that this is not just about breaking one prompt into parts (like MCP does). In MCP, you're still driving one model to do multiple tasks in a structured way ‚Äî like giving it a checklist. But with A2A, you're creating actual independent agents, each focused on their own specialty, talking and collaborating like co-workers. It‚Äôs a more modular, flexible setup.
Another interesting angle: A2A could enable lightweight agents on the edge (like inside your mobile app) to talk to more powerful agents running on the backend. That could mean faster responses, less data transfer, and better privacy ‚Äî especially useful in customer-facing apps.
In the customer onboarding space, this opens up a lot. You often need:
One agent to recommend the right financial product
Another to verify documents and extract data
A third to assess customer risk
With A2A, these specialized agents can be trained once and reused across different workflows ‚Äî no need to build new agents or clunky rule-switching logic every time something changes.
We‚Äôre exploring how this could help improve our own onboarding and document automation flows. Early days, but it feels like a solid step toward building smarter, more adaptable AI systems.

Beyond Fancy Ice Creams: A Wake-Up Call for India‚Äôs Innovation Ecosystem

Union Minister Piyush Goyal recent remarks at Startup Mahakumbh‚Äîmentioning ‚Äúfancy ice creams‚Äù and ‚Äúhyperfast groceries‚Äù‚Äîsparked strong reactions across India‚Äôs startup world.

But perhaps the criticism should be seen less as dismissal and more as deliberate tough love. Goyal, one of India‚Äôs most effective communicators, likely chose his words to provoke reflection‚Äînot discourage innovation. Like a parent urging a child to aim higher, his message is clear: India must prioritize deep tech innovation if it wants to lead globally.

While consumption-driven startups have created jobs, attracted FDI, and modernized services, they often reorganize existing spending patterns rather than build long-term capability. True nation-changing innovation‚Äîsemiconductors, robotics, EVs, AI‚Äîrequires patient investment, research, and ecosystem-wide support.

Countries like South Korea (electronics), Israel (cybersecurity), and China (EVs & automation) made deliberate, long-term bets on deep tech‚Äîand are reaping the benefits.

The responsibility doesn‚Äôt lie with founders alone. Government, academia, investors, and corporate leaders must work in concert. That means more public funding for research, deeper academia-industry collaboration, and a culture that celebrates solving hard problems‚Äînot just scaling fast.

India doesn‚Äôt need to abandon consumer innovation. But we must balance it with bold, future-defining bets. The next chapter of our startup story should be about building the technology the world uses‚Äînot just delivering it faster.

If this speech makes us pause and ask: What kind of innovation will define India in 2047?, then it has served its purpose.

Let‚Äôs celebrate our progress‚Äîbut also raise our ambitions.

For 90 years, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has done just that. Quietly shaping the way India banks, transacts, and trusts its financial system.

From coins in our pockets to the tap of a phone, the RBI‚Äôs journey is stitched into the fabric of our daily lives.

As we continue celebrating #RBIWeek at Signzy, today‚Äôs spotlight is on the milestones that made this institution a force of stability, innovation, and progress ‚Äî one policy at a time.

Whether it was introducing Asia‚Äôs first deposit insurance to protect small depositors, driving credit towards agriculture and small businesses through priority sector lending, or nationalizing banks to make financial services accessible to millions ‚Äî each milestone shaped the way India banks today üí™

In recent years, the RBI has continued to adapt ‚Äî enabling UPI‚Äôs rapid growth into a global payments benchmark, making onboarding simpler with Video KYC, and exploring the future of money through digital currency pilots. ‚Üí Exploring alternative funding options beyond traditional deposits.
‚ÜíIdentifying new revenue streams through value-added services and premium offerings.

The changing dynamics of the deposit market underscore the need for banks to adapt their business models and embrace innovation.

We are known for our innovative approach, but might not always have robust risk management and compliance teams like traditional banks.

Financial institutions, regardless of size or approach, I urge you to prioritise KYC and AML compliance.

AMBs are responsible for verifying merchant identities, business nature, and adherence to regulations like the Aadhaar Act 2016.

2. Risk-based classifications

They need to classify merchants into risk categories and prohibited categories include illegal activities and unregulated financial products.

3. Continuous monitoring

Keep track of suspicious activity, verify online merchant websites, and prevent cash withdrawal transactions through BAP.

This ensures responsible growth of BAP while maintaining a secure and trustworthy digital payments environment.

Yet another step towards building a secure digital payments infrastructure in India.


Three days ago, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) issued guidelines to strengthen regulations for Payment Aggregators (PAs).

These directions cover the following key points:

1. Data storage: From August 2025, only card issuers and networks can store card transaction data. Others must delete all stored data and can only keep the last four digits and issuer name for tracking purposes.

These moves significantly reduce the risk of data breaches and protect consumers' financial information.

2. Net worth requirements: Non-bank PA-Ps need a minimum net worth of Rs 15 crore to apply for authorization and Rs 25 crore by March 2028. Non-compliant existing PA-Ps must cease operations by July 2025 or their bank accounts will be closed by October 2025.

This not only protects consumers but also fosters a level playing field within the industry.

3. Authorization: PA-P companies need to inform the RBI within 60 days if they want to seek authorization. Existing players must apply by May 2025.

4. Merchant monitoring: PAs must continuously monitor merchants' transactions, emphasise stricter merchant onboarding procedures, set risk-based payment limits, and identify potential risks early.

In my opinion, such clear guidelines only boost the PA ecosystem, promote ethical practices, and ultimately enhance digital trust.

postContent:
The RBI's recent action on Paytm Payments Bank (PPB) has brought up discussions about potential gaps in India's financial regulations.


This raises two important questions:

1. Should we broaden the scope of "systemically important institutions" (D-SIBs)?

Currently, only a few large banks are classified as D-SIBs by the RBI. 

However, the PPB case highlights how even smaller entities can pose systemic risks if they falter. 

Experts suggest expanding the D-SIB framework to include:

‚Üí Payments banks: Their critical role in the financial ecosystem necessitates closer scrutiny.

‚Üí Fintech companies: Their dominance in payments, especially foreign players like PhonePe and Google Pay, raises concerns about potential instability.

‚Üí Other key players: Entities like the National Payments Corporation of India (NPCI) and account aggregators (AAs) might also warrant inclusion.

2. Should we consider an activity-based approach to risk assessment?

The current system focuses on the size and interconnectedness of institutions. 

Experts propose a shift to an "activity-based" model that evaluates the inherent risks of specific activities, like payment processing, regardless of the entity performing them.

Further considerations:

‚Üí Pricing of UPI: The debate around free UPI transactions continues. While it benefits consumers, it raises concerns about the sustainability of the system and the potential dominance of foreign players.

‚Üí KYC compliance: The Paytm episode underscores the importance of strict KYC norms for all financial entities, including fintech companies.

We believe finding a balance between innovation and regulation is crucial for the healthy development of the Indian financial ecosystem.

While V-KYC is a powerful tool, it is important to use it responsibly. 

Companies that use V-KYC must prioritise data security and obtain user consent before collecting and using biometric data.

postContent:
I became a father 2 years ago. While my child doesn‚Äôt play video games yet, I am still afraid the moment she starts fiddling with my phone. Many of my friends with older children worry about their Internet or social media usage. Still, most parents don‚Äôt realise that a much darker underworld hides inside many popular online or #mobilegames that children play. 

Most multi-user games have in-built chat features that let players to chat or send messages to each other. And Internet and news media is full of horror stories of how children or teens are bullied or harassed by other gamers or even targeted by adult predators through chat messages. 

As parents, nothing is scarier than the thought of having your child fall victim to these online bullies or predators. And yet, we as parents can do nothing other than denying our children access to mobile devices or computers, which is simply impractical in this day and age. 

The onus is clearly on the gaming industry to do more to safeguard our children. Ensuring full #KYC for all users is an important first step and this is what I talk about in my piece, published in The Times Of India earlier this week. Would love to hear thoughts how we can make gaming and online safer..

It's been difficult to scroll through LinkedIn lately without seeing posts from talented professionals who have been impacted by recent layoffs at companies, some of whom have devoted 20+ years of their careers to these organizations. Our hearts go out to all those who have been affected by these difficult decisions.

As a founder, I understand the uncertainty and fear that can come with job loss, especially in the current economic climate. But I also know that as a community, we can come together to support one another and navigate this situation.

Here at Signzy, we're committed to building a strong network of professionals and entrepreneurs. If you or someone you know has been impacted by layoffs, please reach out to us for support. Whether it's connecting you with resources or offering a listening ear, we're here to help. We also have few open positions which you can see if fit. 

Let's come together as a community to support one another during these trying times. Together, we can navigate this and come out stronger on the other side
